title: Dalip Kumar Tiwana first writer to Padma Shree award
text:
Comment 
Novelist and short story writer in Punjabi, Dalip Kaur Tiwana, on 13 October said that she was returning the Padma Shree, the country’s fourth highest civilian award, she was presented with in 2004 for Literature and Education. 
Tiwana, 80, is the first writer to give up a Padma award in order to express “solidarity with the writers who are protesting against cultural intolerance in the society and politics”. 
“I wanted to give up something big for a cause which is close to my heart, and this is my way of registering protest . Minorities are being crushed and writers and rationalists are being murdered, and the right to express is suppressed,” said Tiwana. She also bagged the Sahitya Akademi Award in 1971 for her novel Eho Hamara Jivana (This our life). 
At the same time, Assamese litterateur and journalist Homen Borgohain also returned his Sahitya Akademi award, which he received in 1978 for his novel Pita Putra. 
He protested against the lynching of a man in Dadri area over rumours of cow slaughter and the “growing fascist tendency in the country” and forces that are “trying to hit at the core ideology of Indian civilisation”. 
Tiwana used to teach Punjabi at Patiala’s Punjab University and is now a writer-in-residence there. She said “In this land of Gautama Buddha, the atrocities committed on Sikhs in 1984 and now on the Muslims is an utter disgrace to our state and society.” 
“In the 21st century, we are killing those who stand up for truth; it’s a shame,” said Tiwana. “I laud this form of protest and hope this will make people think and remind them that secularism is most important. */
